Introduction
The &utils; package provides a space for utility functions from a variety of &GAP; packages to be collected together into a single package. In this way it is hoped that they will become more visible to other package authors. Any package author who transfers a function to &utils; will become an author of &utils;. This package relies on modifications to the library files oper.g and global.g. It appears that these modifications will not appear in a GAP release until at least version 4.8.3, so development of this package is suspended until further notice.
The package is loaded with the command
gap> LoadPackage( "utils" );
The current version is &UTILSVERSION; for &GAP; 4.8, released on &UTILSLONGRELEASEDATE;.
The package may be obtained as a compressed tar file &UTILSTARFILENAME; by ftp from one of the following sites:
any &GAP; archive, e.g. http://www.gap-system.org/Packages/packages.html;
the Bangor site: http://www.maths.bangor.ac.uk/chda/&UTILSHTMLFILENAME;;
The package also has a GitHub repository: https://github.com/cdwensley/utils.
Once the package is loaded, the manual doc/manual.pdf can be found in the documentation folder. The html versions, with or without MathJax, may be rebuilt as follows:
gap> ReadPackage( "utils", "makedocrel.g" );
It is possible to check that the package has been installed correctly by running the test files:
gap> ReadPackage( "utils", "tst/testall.g" ); #I Testing .../pkg/utils/tst/lists.tst ...
Additional information can be found on the Computational Higher-dimensional Discrete Algebra website at http://pages.bangor.ac.uk/~mas023/chda/.
The transfer procedure
The process for transferring utility functions from an existing package (the Home package, say) to Utils should only require the following steps from Home's author(s).
Offer functions for inclusion. This may be simply done by emailing a list of functions. More usefully, email the following files: home.gd, home.gi, home.tst and home.xml,
Once the functions have been included in Utils, and a new version of Utils released, remove the functions from Home, and add Utils to the list of required packages in PackageInfo.g.
The following procedure is useded for transferring a function func from Home to Utils.
There are two cases to consider. If the functions being transferred have names of the form Home_this_func, then it is probably sensible to change the name in Utils to ThisFunc (if not already in use). In this case there is no duplication of declarations or implementations. However, once the functions have appeared in a new release of Utils, the author(s) of Home will have a significant amount of editing to do.
In the second case, the functions names in Utils will be the same as in Home, and the following steps are proposed.
For each function func copy the code into the appropriate *.gd, *.gi files in Utils.
For attributes and properties this duplication produces no obvious effect in &GAP;.
For operations the following warning is printed when the second of Home or Utils is loaded:
#I equal requirements in multiple declarations for operation `func'.
For a global function glob duplicate declarations produce an error. This is avoided as follows.
The library file oper.g has been modified to include the declaration of empty lists GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_LIST, GLOBAL_REINSTALLATION_LIST and GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_COUNT. Also, in oper.g, the functions DeclareGlobalFunction and InstallGlobalFunction have been modified to prevent the execution of a second declaration or installation of functions in these lists. The revised code in oper.g is shown in Appendix .
The function AllowGlobalRedeclaration is used (in file utils/lib/first.gd) to add "glob" to the list GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_LIST, while the function AllowGlobalReinstallation is used (in file utils/lib/last.gd) to add glob to the list GLOBAL_REINSTALLATION_LIST.
To allow for functions installed just using BIND_GLOBAL, there is (in file global.g) a function AllowGlobalRebinding and lists GLOBAL_REBINDING_LIST, GLOBAL_REBINDING_COUNT.
Copy and edit any tests and documentation into the corresponding *.tst, *.xml files in Utils.
When all is working satisfactorily, publish a new version of Utils; then notify the author(s) of Home, asking them to check that the functions are working correctly. These checks should involve loading Utils first, and then Home, and, in a separate &GAP; session, loading Home first, and then Utils.
The author(s) of Home remove the declarations and implementations of all the transferred functions from their files, and (possibly) edit references to them in their manual and tests.
They make Utils a required package in PackageInfo.g and publish a new release of Home.
In the next version of Utils remove each "glob" from GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_LIST and each glob from GLOBAL_REINSTALLATION_LIST or GLOBAL_REBINDING_LIST.
Comments on the transfer procedure for global functions
Suppose that, at the start of the transfer of glob from Home to Utils, the version of Home is 6.78 and the version of Utils is 2.34. In what follows, val refers to the value of GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_COUNT[pos] where pos is the position of "glob" in GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_LIST.
There are three stages to the process.
In the first stage the declaration, implementation, documentation and tests referring to glob are copied to files in Utils. Suppose Home is loaded first, so that glob is both declared and implemented from Home. Then, when Utils is loaded,
ISBOUND_GLOBAL will be true for glob and so val will be set to 1 by first.gd;
the declaration of glob is then found, and ignored, but val is increased to 2;
when the implementation of glob is found, it is ignored because val is too large.
Alternatively, suppose Utils is loaded first, so that:
ISBOUND_GLOBAL will be false for glob and so val will be set to 0 by first.gd;
the declaration of glob is then accepted and val is increased to 1;
when the implementation of glob is found, it is accepted because val is less than 2.
Then, when Home is loaded,
the declaration of glob is found, and ignored, and val is increased to 2;
when the implementation of glob is found, it is ignored because val is too large.
When all the tests pass, version 2.35 of Utils is published, and the authors of Home notified.
In the second stage, the authors of Home do their own tests. If satisfied, they remove all declaration and implementation code for glob from Home, and add Utils to their list of required packages in their PackageInfo.g. Now, in a new &GAP; session, when RequirePackage(home); is called, Utils is loaded first, providing the declaration and implementation of glob. Further tests are then required to check that any other Home functions which use glob still work correctly. If still satisfied, the authors publish version 6.79 of Home.
In the final stage, "glob" and glob are removed from GLOBAL_REDECLARATION_LIST and GLOBAL_REINSTALLATION_LIST respectively (ditto GLOBAL_REBINDING_LIST). The additional code in oper.g (or global.g) no longer applies to glob, and version 2.36 of Utils may be published.
